text: I'm Richmond Ola I'm the enterprise CIO
at Emory and that includes both
university operations as well as the
healthcare operations my role is really
designed to try to bring the enterprise
together and find synergies across the
different IT functions and to really
reduce duplication wherever possible
we're based in Atlanta Georgia about
36,000 employees about 18,000 students
and about 3,000 faculty the faculty are
always looking for the latest and
greatest tools we're always looking for
the latest and greatest tools to either
create efficiencies or create new
discoveries and AWS met that need in
many cases we're using you know
traditional ec2 s3 we've done a lot of
the work with serverless compute those
who are using lambdas a lot and then
we've got back-end databases we're using
native security tools the I am product
those are tools we run the environment
in but that an end user would would
never really be thinking about so the
biggest benefit for us was really
shrinking at time to science giving
faculty the tools that they wanted doing
that in an agile timely fashion and at
the same time combining that with the
social security practices that allowed
them to do their work in a secure manner
and stay out of trouble in our genetics
area we they had a grant materialized at
the last minute this they sometimes do
and they needed extraordinarily large
amount of processing to do that work we
were able to work with them help them
spin up to 200 very large UC ec2
instances get their processing done in a
matter of days finish the work and go
out and get the grant so that ability to
just provision on demand
to address unexpected scenarios there's
just an incredible benefit for us
